newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Singapore shares tick up at open, may trend higher.
newsitem.headline: Singapore shares tick up at open, may trend higher.

text.p: Singapore shares opened slightly higher on Tuesday in thin volume.
Dealers said activity might pick up later as funds reappeared after holidays in London and the U.S. on Monday.
"I think it will be a little more lively today but we're still not expecting much movement away from these ranges," said one local dealer.
"We see a gentle rise towards 2,100 points on the index and then a drift off again," said another.
The benchmark 30-share Straits Times Industrials Index (STII) was 3.30 points higher at 2,059.62 by 0150 GMT.

Malaysian shares dominated early volume with timber group Construction and Supplies House Bhd down a cent (0.69 U.S. cents) to Singapore $2.27 as recent rumours of a merger with an unnamed group faded.
The UOB OTC index of Malaysian shares was down 4.30 at 1160.34 points.
Of the STII shares, Singapore Telecom was up three cents at S$2.49 on bargain buying by some funds after a recent sell-off.
"Singapore Telecom has underperformed the market and, as it is a major index stock, it is being bought by index matchers," said another dealer.
